content.description: Hallucinogen Persisting Perception Disorder (HPPD) involves the re-experiencing of perceptual disturbances that were experienced during hallucinogen intoxication, even after the substance has been eliminated from the body. These symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment and are not due to another medical condition or mental disorder.

mechanisms: Persistent changes in cortical visual processing pathways, particularly occipital cortex hyperexcitability.
Alterations in serotonergic neurotransmission (5-HT2A receptor activity) due to hallucinogen exposure.
Disruption of sensory gating mechanisms in thalamocortical circuits.

content.diagnostic_criteria: Following cessation of hallucinogen use, the person re-experiences one or more perceptual symptoms that were experienced while intoxicated with the hallucinogen (e.g., geometric hallucinations, false perceptions of movement, flashes of color, afterimages, halos around objects, size distortions). Symptoms cause distress or impairment, are not attributable to another medical condition, and are not better explained by another mental disorder.
content.prevalence: Exact prevalence is unknown; estimated to be rare, but underreported due to stigma or misattribution to other conditions.
content.age_of_onset: Typically occurs in late adolescence to young adulthood, corresponding to peak hallucinogen use.
content.prognosis: Varies; some experience spontaneous remission over months to years, while others have persistent symptoms. Prognosis is better with abstinence and treatment of comorbid anxiety.

history: Detailed substance use history (types of hallucinogens, frequency, last use)
medical_workup: EEG or brain imaging if needed to exclude seizures or lesions

severity_levels.mild: Intermittent disturbances with minimal functional impact
severity_levels.moderate: Frequent disturbances causing anxiety or concentration issues
severity_levels.severe: Persistent, intrusive disturbances severely impairing daily function

environmental: Use of high-dose or multiple hallucinogens

impact_on_life.occupational: Difficulty with tasks requiring sustained visual focus
impact_on_life.emotional: Heightened anxiety and fear of 'going crazy'

psychotherapy: Psychoeducation to reduce anxiety about symptoms
CBT targeting distress tolerance and anxiety management
Mindfulness-based strategies to reduce symptom preoccupation
medications: Clonidine or SSRIs for comorbid anxiety/depression
lifestyle_interventions: Strict abstinence from hallucinogens and other psychoactive substances
Stress management and regular sleep patterns
care_coordination: Collaboration with neurology and ophthalmology if indicated
Support groups for individuals with HPPD

treatment_goals: Reduce frequency and intensity of perceptual disturbances
missed_diagnosis_factors: Attributing symptoms solely to anxiety or migraine without substance use history
Failure to elicit past hallucinogen use during evaluation
overdiagnosis_factors: Mislabeling normal perceptual variations as pathological
Confusing post-hallucinogen flashbacks with primary psychotic disorders
warning_signs: Visual distortions persisting beyond acute intoxication
Increased anxiety in visually stimulating environments
self_help_strategies: Practice mindfulness to reduce symptom distress

adolescents: Symptoms may interfere with school performance and social interaction
adults: Work limitations in visually intensive jobs

real_life_examples: A 19-year-old college student experiences persistent halos and visual snow months after using LSD, leading them to avoid bright environments.
A 27-year-old artist notices recurring geometric patterns in vision long after last psilocybin use, causing distress when painting.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek help if perceptual disturbances persist beyond the expected intoxication period, cause distress, or interfere with daily functioning.

positive_factors: Early recognition and cessation of all hallucinogen use
challenging_factors: Lack of access to knowledgeable clinicians
